This solves the issue with compacted logs. Tested and working well, but it creates a new problem.
The user might decide to use the NONE Acknowledgement Strategy together with enable.auto.commit=false.
https://smallrye.io/smallrye-reactive-messaging/2.1.1/apidocs/org/eclipse/microprofile/reactive/messaging/Acknowledgment.Strategy.html#NONE
Basically the user wishes to never commit (there's a few use cases for this).
But with the implementation as is we will spring a leak. The received offset queue will grow without being emptied since there will be no call to ack. It looks to me that the Incoming publishers and connectors are decoupled in such a way that the connector doesn't know what strategy is configured.
I see two possible solutions:


Have the commit strategy be configurable like the nack strategy. Have the default depend on enable.auto.commit but let the user configure ignore if they wish.


If we have more than max.poll.records (default 500) received messages without committing a single one then we can assume that the user configured to never commit. In this case we can just turn the strategy off.


1 is much simpler to maintain, but is a bit onerous on the user and requires proper documentation.
2 requires no action from the user (should just work), but is a harder to reason and maintain.
What do you think? If there was some way for the connector to know that NONE was used during setup that would be great, but I'm not seeing it.

(1) definitely. We can use "enable.auto.commit" to determine the default. Adding another attribute to configure the strategy would be nice and allow configuring the application to use the current model.
That's what I wrote on the SmallRye Mailing list (for traceability purpose):

To implement this, we would need a new attribute to set the strategy:

commit every offset when the message is acked -> Today's solution
let kafka auto-commit -> enable the auto-commit and ignore acks from the app
batch/cursor tracking strategy -> the strategy described in this mail (which would need a > better name)
Each of them has pros and cons, so they would need to be clearly documented.
Line 158 and 163 are the only actual changes. We have to inform the commit handler that a re-balance took place so it can reset its internal data structures.
